newsitem.title: USA: SEC sues video equipment maker, chairman for manipulation.
newsitem.headline: SEC sues video equipment maker, chairman for manipulation.

text.p: The Securities and Exchange Commission said Thursday it has filed a lawsuit against Systems of Excellence Inc. and its chairman, Charles Huttoe, for alleged "massive market manipulation" involving shares of the company.

In a civil complaint filed in federal district court here, the agency alleged that Huttoe, a 49-year-old Miami resident, secretly distributed about 43 million company shares to his family members and corporations.

He allegedly manipulated the market by issuing false, favourable information concerning the company, using a stock promoter, and then selling his shares after its price had artificially risen, the SEC said.

Huttoe allegedly "engaged in a massive coverup," after the company's auditors found evidence of unregistered distribution of the company's shares and raised questions about the matter in mid-September, the SEC said.
Systems of Excellence, a maker of video teleconferencing equipment, has offices in McLean, Va., and Coral Gables, Fla.
Also named in the civil complaint are six companies, including stock promoter SGA Goldstar Research Inc., and certain relatives of Huttoe, including his wife Karen Purvis, his mother and a niece.
The SEC's action comes after it suspended trading of the company's stock for 10 days beginning Oct. 7 because of questions about the accuracy of information disseminated to the market.
The SEC is seeking to recover at least $10 million that investors allegedly lost because of Huttoe's and other defendants' wrongdoing.
The SEC has asked the court to issue a temporary restraining order, a preliminary injunction and other emergency relief, including the freezing of the company's bank accounts.
Cynthia Gramer, a company spokesperson, said from Boston that "a group of people have taken the company in hand.
"They are doing everything in their power to uncover what was wrong and make it right," she said. "Apparently there is a great deal that needs to be fixed."
Huttoe could not be reached for comment.
